captions.text:
[ ''Mother's'' Voice ] It's sad when
a mother has to speak the words...

but l couldn't allow them
to believe that l would commit murder.

They'll put him away now,
as l should have years ago.

He was always bad,
and in the end...

he intended to tell them l killed
those girls and that man,

as if l could do anything
except sit and stare,

like one
of his stuffed birds.

They know l can't even
move a finger, and l won't.

l'll iust sit here and be quiet,
just in case they do suspect me.

They're probably watching me.
Well, let them.

Let them see
what kind of a person l am.

l'm not even
gonna swat that fly.

l hope they are watching.
They'll see.

and they'll say, ''Why, she
wouldn't even harm a fly.''

Closed-Captioned By
Captions, Inc. Los Angeles

title: Psycho (12/12) Movie CLIP - She Wouldn't Even Harm a Fly (1960) HD

comments.author: desertdispatch

comments.text:
+degree7 A lot of truth in what you say - I know there is a school of 
thought that "Psycho" was the original "slasher" film and set the stage for 
things like the "Freddy/Friday the 13th" films and the like, although to be 
honest I'm not sure that's what Hitchcock had in mind.  But you're right -- 
the Academy doesn't really take horror films as seriously as they do other 
kinds of films: otherwise Boris Karloff would surely have gotten an award.
comments.author: Partnerfrance

comments.text:
Yeah, Silence of the Lambs is more psychological thriller to me as well. 
But Psycho is that and horror, I mean, the shower scene is iconic and 
terrifying.
comments.author: degree7

comments.text:
+degree7 Fair enough, although they came pretty close when they awarded all 
those Oscars to "Silence of the Lambs".  I guess you could make a case that 
neither "Psycho" nor "Silence of the Lambs" were really "horror" films, 
though -- perhaps more "psychological thrillers"?
comments.author: Partnerfrance

comments.text: The Academy generally doesn't give out awards to horror films.

comments.author: Paul Abbott

comments.text:
Definitely one of the best scenes. Norman is just sitting in a room, 
quietly, all the drama's been done, the movie is almost over. His "mother" 
tells us how harmless she is. I liked her speech on how harmless she was, 
but the best part was when she said " I'm not even going to swat that fly. 
I hope they are watching. They'll see, they'll see and they'll know- and 
they'll say- why she wouldn't even harm a fly!" And Norman looks up at the 
camera, a psychopathic smile on his face, which then turns into a skeletal 
grin.﻿

comments.text:
+Alan Younger
Virginia Gregg was a versatile character actor.  She was a member of Jack 
Webb's stable of performers and can be seen in many episodes of his iconic 
Dragnet series.
comments.author: frisco21

comments.text:
The Mother was actually voiced by three separate people in this film: 
Virginia Gregg, Jeanette Nolan, and Paul Jasmin. In this scene 
specifically, I believe she is voiced by Virginia Gregg, but as all three 
were uncredited, and there is no precise way of knowing, I cannot say that 
as a fact.

comments.text:
Does Norman actually have to pretend for himself that his mother still 
lives just to avoid gis guilt for killing her, or does he actually believe 
HIMSELF that his mother is still alive?﻿
comments.author: Special Power

comments.text:
I think Norman is a completely split personality. After "mother" kills 
people, Norman seems to have no memory of what she did and is horrified 
when he finds the bodies.
comments.author: Catzilla

comments.text: +Special Power eh who knows that's what he did in real life
comments.author: WhenTheyCry

comments.text:
+Alan Younger Yes, but during the movie, he's not yet his mother himself, 
but he's conviced, he BELIVES that his mother is alive. So why did he try 
to hide her from anyone else during that movie? Why did he put her in a 
basement? Why did he hide her from Abrogast, or then the sister and the 
boyfriend of the woman his mother killed. Why? If he's feeling like his 
mother is alive, then it wouldn't be a problem for him to let anyone else 
see her, right?
comments.author: Special Power

comments.text: Because he's insane
comments.author: Jeamus Ken

comments.text:
It seems like a bit of both. He felt so guilty for killing his mother that 
he pretended she was still alive. However, he soon became so convinced that 
she was still alive that his mind created a split personality. One is, of 
course, Norman. The other is Mother. So, yes, he does believe that she is 
actually alive, because in a way, she is. She is, quite literally, part of 
him. He IS his mother.
comments.author: Alan Younger

comments.text:
The series is great but it also seems to take a departure from the movie 
(and I assume the book) in that Norma (his mother) smothers him but does 
outright torment him. In that sense his psychosis seems to be both 
neurological + psychological in origin rather than just being a product of 
his mother's torment.

comments.author: Douglas Butcher

comments.text:
Pause at 1:29 and you'll see something even more remarkable.  Compare this 
scene to 7:30 of Part 10 of "Lady on a Train".  Perkins was a homosexual 
and had very feminine features. It's quite astonishing, but Perkins' 
sinister smile here and Deanna Durbin's beautiful smile in "Lady on a 
Train" are almost identical.
